page.title: Main page - choose lesson part
page.contents:
You do not have to finish the whole lesson in one sitting.  You may retry the lesson if you are not happy with the outcome.  Here is a "map" of the lesson.  I am including this so that you can check whether you have completed all parts.  Note in particular that for some reason the moodle lessons sometimes skip the reflective writing items (I haven't figured out why), so this map helps you figure out where those should be:

Choose one of the following lesson parts.  When you have finished that part of the lesson you will be brought back to this page.  When you have finished all parts of the lesson click the "OK, I'm done" button to end the lesson.

answer.answer_text: Lecture 3-2: Visualizing Vector Addition and Subtraction
Lecture 3-3: Connecting Vectors to Ideas from Motion Diagrams
All Reflective Writing Pages: This is a fail safe in case the lesson navigation fails and you can't view on of the Reflective Writing pages. Normally there should be no need to click this.

page.title: Online Lecture 3-1: Vector Definitions
page.contents:
Watch this video.

This covers some of the material in section 3-1 in the text.  If you have the text you may want to supplement the lecture by reading/skimming this section.

answer.answer_text: Click this button when you have finished watching the lecture.

page.title: Cluster
page.contents: Cluster

page.title: Identify direction of vector 1
page.contents:
Bo and Luke Duke are driving west when they drive their car off the end of an old collapsed bridge (Yeeeeee Haaaawww!) as shown in the diagram.  At the instant they go off the end of the bridge their speed is 35 m/s, and they leave the bridge going 15º above the horizontal.  A road crew conveniently left a set of axes hanging off the end of the bridge as shown.

Choose a correct way of writing the velocity of the car from among the options below.  More than one answer may be correct, but you only need to choose one.

answer.response: No, the angle between the car's velocity and the x-axis is 165 degrees.
No, the angle between the car's velocity and the x-axis is 165 degrees.
Not specific enough. We know enough to give the answer more precisely than this.

page.title: Identify direction of vector 2
page.contents:
Bart has decided to "welcome" Lisa home by skateboarding off the roof to land right in front of her.  He is going down the roof at 6 m/s.  The roof has a 20° pitch as shown.  Homer brought home a set of axes from the power plant the other week and didn't know what to do with them, so they are still leaning against the front of the house as shown.

Choose a correct way of writing the Bart's velocity from among the options below.  More than one answer may be correct, but you only need to choose one.

answer.response: No, Bart's velocity is 25 degrees clockwise from the x-axis. By convention clockwise angles are negative.
No, the vector is drawn above the axes, but the direction it points is below the direction that the x-axis points in.
Not specific enough. We know enough to give the answer more precisely than this.

page.title: End of cluster 3-1
page.contents: End of cluster

page.title: Cluster
page.contents: Cluster

page.title: choose correct vector add 1
page.contents: For the pair of vectors, a and b shown below, choose the diagram which correctly shows the addition, a+b.

answer.response: No, the vectors should be arranged head to tail in order to add them.
No, look at "where we started", at the tail of a. The resultant vector (the red one) should start at that location. So in C it is flipped around backwards.
No, the vectors should be arranged head to tail in order to add them.
No, notice that b has been flipped around backwards. This is a - b.

page.title: choose correct vector subtract 1
page.contents: For the pair of vectors, a and b shown below, choose the diagram which correctly shows the subtraction, a-b.

answer.response: No, look at "where we started", at the tail of a. The resultant vector (the red one) should start at that location. So in A it is flipped around backwards.
No, to carry out the subtraction we need to "flip" b end-for-end. Also, the red resultant vector is pointing the wrong way for the addition drawn.
No, to carry out the subtraction we need to "flip" b end-for-end.

No, to subtract we should "flip" b end-for-end and then add. You may have been taught in a different course to do vector subtraction by arranging the vectors tail to tail. This answer illustrates why this is a bad idea. Having arranged them tail to tail it is difficult to figure out which way to make the result point since both possibilities make it point towards one of the heads of the vectors being subtracted. In E the result is flipped around backwards.

page.title: End of cluster 3-2B
page.contents: End of cluster

page.title: choose correct vector subtract 2
page.contents: For the pair of vectors, a and b shown below, choose the diagram which correctly shows the subtraction, a-b.

answer.response: No, in A the vectors have been added, not subtracted. To carry out the subtraction we need to "flip" b end-for-end.
No this is b - a. The wrong vector has been flipped end-for-end.
No, look at "where we started", at the tail of a. The resultant vector (the red one) should start at that location. So in D it is flipped around backwards.

No, to subtract we should "flip" b end-for-end and then add. You may have been taught in a different course to do vector subtraction by arranging the vectors tail to tail. This answer illustrates why this is a bad idea. Having arranged them tail to tail it is difficult to figure out which way to make the result point since both possibilities make it point towards one of the heads of the vectors being subtracted. In E the result is flipped around backwards.

page.title: Choose correct acceleration vector 1
page.contents: For the fragment of a motion diagram shown, choose the correct acceleration vector.

answer.response: No, you've chosen the vector you would get from adding the two velocities. But we get the acceleration by subtracting.

No, perhaps you are confusing acceleration with velocity so you are choosing the vector which looks "tangent to the path". The acceleration is obtained from the velocity vectors by vector subtraction.

No, when an object moves in a curved path the acceleration vector points to the inside of the curve, not the outside. Try carrying out the vector subtraction. If you tried to do the vector subtraction perhaps you took vi - vf instead of vf - vi ?
No, the object is speeding up, so its acceleration vector should point inward and **forward** but you've chosen inward and back.

page.title: Reflect on what you have learned (final summary)
page.contents:
You should already have a sheet of paper that you wrote some things on after watching Lecture 2.  If you don't already have that (perhaps because you are watching the videos out of sequence) then go back to Lecture 2, watch it, answer the questions and then start your writing.  Then come back to this page.

Under what you wrote for Lecture 2 write a heading saying "End of Lectures".  

Under that heading answer the following questions:

1. Point of confusion: Identify something that confused you during the lecture.  If you are still confused by it then try to explain, in reasonable detail, exactly why you are confused.  If you are no longer confused then explain how you resolved your confusion (i.e. what realizations led you to no longer being confused).  Be as specific as you can about the nature of your confusion.  It is not acceptable to simply say that you were not confused by anything.  If you think you were not confused by anything then you are not thinking about the material carefully enough.

2. Question beyond the lecture: Ask a question that goes beyond what was covered in the lectures.  This could be a question about a topic that you think might be related to the lectures, or something that you suspect might be a more advanced topic that the material in these lectures might eventually lead to.  Or it might be something that I mentioned briefly, but didn't go into detail on.  Make your question as specific as you can.

3. What does the symbol, \( \hat{i} \), (often described as "i-hat") mean?  What does the symbol, \( \hat{j} \), mean?  I have not defined it, but can you guess  what the symbol, \( \hat{k} \), must mean?

You will scan this sheet, along with an addition to your cheat sheet, and submit it on moodle under the Written Response for this lesson.

page.title: Cluster
page.contents: Cluster

page.title: choose the correct component form expression 1
page.contents: For the vector in the diagram below, choose the correct way to write the vector in component form.

answer.response: No, you have found the magnitude of the vector. I have asked you to write the vector itself (in coordinate form) not its magnitude.
No, that is magnitude, direction form. I asked for coordinate form, which in this case is **much** easier to write down.

page.title: All reflections
page.contents:
This is only here so that if the Lesson navigation failed and you couldn't access one of the Reflective Writing pages you can view their content here.  Most of the time there should be no need for you to visit this page.

----------After Lecture 3-----------

Take out a piece of paper.  Write "PHYS 1101 - Response to Unit 3 Video Lectures" across the top of the paper and put your name in an upper corner of the page.  Write a big heading saying "Lectures 1-3".  

Under that answer these questions:

1. Point of confusion: Identify something that confused you during the lecture.  If you are still confused by it then try to explain, in reasonable detail, exactly why you are confused.  If you are no longer confused then explain how you resolved your confusion (i.e. what realizations led you to no longer being confused).  Be as specific as you can about the nature of your confusion.  It is not acceptable to simply say that you were not confused by anything.  If you think you were not confused by anything then you are not thinking about the material carefully enough.

2. Something you have seen before: Identify something from any of the videos on this unit that you have seen before.  If it was presented differently from how you have seen it previously then briefly describe the difference.  It is not acceptable to say that nothing in the videos was something you have seen before.  All knowledge is built on earlier knowledge and there must be something in these videos that was at least somewhat familiar.

3. Suppose we have some vector, \( \vec{A} \) which points in the positive x-direction (i.e. it points parallel to the x-axis, in the direction defined as positive for x).  We have another vector, \( \vec{B} \) which points in the negative x-direction.

  • In your own words explain  the similarities and differences between the vector, \( \vec{A} \), its magnitude, \( |\vec{A}| \equiv A \) and its  x-component, \( A_x \).
  • In your own words explain  the similarities and differences between the vector, \( \vec{B} \), its magnitude, \( |\vec{B}| \equiv B \) and its  x-component, \( B_x \).

You will add more to this sheet after some of the other lectures in this unit.

------------After Lecture 4-----------

You should already have a sheet of paper that you wrote some things on after watching Lectures 1-3.  If you don't already have that (perhaps because you are watching the videos out of sequence) then go back to Lecture 3, watch it, answer the questions and then start your writing.  Then come back to this page.

Under what you wrote for Lectures 1-3 write a heading saying "End of Lesson".  

Under that heading answer the following questions:

1. Point of confusion: Identify something that confused you during the lecture.  If you are still confused by it then try to explain, in reasonable detail, exactly why you are confused.  If you are no longer confused then explain how you resolved your confusion (i.e. what realizations led you to no longer being confused).  Be as specific as you can about the nature of your confusion.  It is not acceptable to simply say that you were not confused by anything.  If you think you were not confused by anything then you are not thinking about the material carefully enough.

2. Question beyond the lecture: Ask a question that goes beyond what was covered in the lectures.  This could be a question about a topic that you think might be related to the lectures, or something that you suspect might be a more advanced topic that the material in these lectures might eventually lead to.  Or it might be something that I mentioned briefly, but didn't go into detail on.  Make your question as specific as you can.

3. What does the symbol, \( \hat{i} \), (often described as "i-hat") mean?  What does the symbol, \( \hat{j} \), mean?  I have not defined it, but can you guess  what the symbol, \( \hat{k} \), must mean?

You will scan this sheet, along with an addition to your cheat sheet, and submit it on moodle under the Written Response for this lesson.

page.title: choose correct vector add 2
page.contents: For the pair of vectors, a and b shown below, choose the diagram which correctly shows the addition, a+b.

answer.response: No, notice that a has been flipped around backwards. This is b - a.
No, the vectors should be arranged head to tail in order to add them.
No, look at "where we started" at the tail of a. The resultant vector (the red one) should start at this location. So it is flipped around backwards in C.
No, the vectors should be arranged head to tail in order to add them.

page.contents: End of cluster

page.title: Choose correct acceleration vector 2
page.contents: For the fragment of a motion diagram shown, choose the correct acceleration vector.

answer.response: No, you've chosen the vector you would get from adding the two velocities. But we get the acceleration by subtracting.
No, the object is slowing down, so its acceleration vector should point inward and **back** but you've chosen inward and forward.

No, when an object moves in a curved path the acceleration vector points to the inside of the curve, not the outside. Try carrying out the vector subtraction. If you tried to do the vector subtraction perhaps you took vi - vf instead of vf - vi ?

No, perhaps you are confusing acceleration with velocity so you are choosing the vector which looks "tangent to the path". The acceleration is obtained from the velocity vectors by vector subtraction.

page.title: Reflect on what you have learned
page.contents:
Take out a piece of paper.  Write "PHYS 1101 - Response to Unit 3 Video Lectures" across the top of the paper and put your name in an upper corner of the page.  Write a big heading saying "Lecture 3".  

Under that answer these questions:

1. Point of confusion: Identify something that confused you during the lecture.  If you are still confused by it then try to explain, in reasonable detail, exactly why you are confused.  If you are no longer confused then explain how you resolved your confusion (i.e. what realizations led you to no longer being confused).  Be as specific as you can about the nature of your confusion.  It is not acceptable to simply say that you were not confused by anything.  If you think you were not confused by anything then you are not thinking about the material carefully enough.

2. Something you have seen before: Identify something from any of the videos on this unit that you have seen before.  If it was presented differently from how you have seen it previously then briefly describe the difference.  It is not acceptable to say that nothing in the videos was something you have seen before.  All knowledge is built on earlier knowledge and there must be something in these videos that was at least somewhat familiar.

3. Suppose we have some vector, \( \vec{A} \) which points in the positive x-direction (i.e. it points parallel to the x-axis, in the direction defined as positive for x).  We have another vector, \( \vec{B} \) which points in the negative x-direction.

  • In your own words explain  the similarities and differences between the vector, \( \vec{A} \), its magnitude, \( |\vec{A}| \equiv A \) and its  x-component, \( A_x \).
  • In your own words explain  the similarities and differences between the vector, \( \vec{B} \), its magnitude, \( |\vec{B}| \equiv B \) and its  x-component, \( B_x \).

You will add more to this sheet after one of the other lectures in this unit.
